Your idea is not unwelcome. I have stated -- a few times -- th=

d is that I do not believe it belongs at the core of JUnit.

As for hoping =
that the JUnit team will assist you, I guess you don't know the JUnit team =
very well. Kent and Erich are nice folks, but they are not active contribut=
ors to JUnit these days. Just look at the gulfs in time between releases to=
 convince yourself. Kent and Erich are not going to jump on board and help =
you with this. They don't have the time or energy. The real activity is in =
add-on projects like JUnit-addons.

JUnit is an excellent example of a well=
-closed package -- not perfect, but pretty damn good -- so that the vast ma=
jority of new features can be implemented easily enough by adding onto JUni=
t rather than changing its core. I think this is a testament to JUnit's des=
ign. The majority of extensions/changes fall into three categories:

* Cust=
omized assertions
* Custom Test Runners
* Custom classes to sit at the root=
 of a TestCase hierarchy

HTMLUnit is an example of the first. Artima's sui=
te runner is an example of the second. StrutsTestCase is an example of the =
third.

A good solution to your problem is the second: a custom test runner=
 with a dependency graph collector/analyzer.
